sections.title: Evaluating Dividend Stocks
sections.subtitle: Find quality dividend payers and avoid the traps

sections.title: The Dividend Quality Checklist
sections.content: Not all dividend stocks are created equal. A high yield means nothing if the company cuts the dividend next quarter. Use these criteria to separate quality dividend payers from risky ones.

points.title: Dividend History (10+ Years)
points.description: Look for companies that have paid dividends consistently for at least 10 years, ideally with annual increases. Dividend Aristocrats (25+ years of increases) are the gold standard.

points.title: Payout Ratio (Under 60%)
points.description: Dividends should be less than 60% of earnings for most companies. This leaves room for dividend growth and provides a cushion during tough times. REITs are an exception (they must pay 90%+).

points.title: Free Cash Flow Coverage
points.description: Dividends should be covered by free cash flow, not just earnings. A company can manipulate earnings but not cash. FCF payout ratio under 70% is healthy.

points.title: Debt Levels (Debt/Equity Under 1.0)
points.description: High debt means interest payments compete with dividends. In a recession, debt payments come first. Look for debt-to-equity under 1.0 for most industries.

points.title: Earnings Growth (Positive Trend)
points.description: Dividends come from earnings. If earnings are declining, dividends will eventually follow. Look for consistent earnings growth over 5-10 years.

sections.title: Red Flags to Avoid
sections.content:
Yield Over 8%: Unless it's a REIT or MLP, yields this high usually signal trouble. The market is pricing in a dividend cut.

Payout Ratio Over 100%: The company is paying more in dividends than it earns. This is unsustainable and a cut is likely.

Declining Revenue: If sales are shrinking, profits will follow, and dividends will be cut. Avoid companies in secular decline.

Recent Dividend Cut: Once a company cuts its dividend, it often cuts again. The trust is broken. Wait for a multi-year recovery before investing.

High Debt with Rising Rates: Companies with lots of debt suffer when interest rates rise. Their interest expenses increase, leaving less for dividends.

One-Time Special Dividends: A large special dividend often means the company has no better use for the cash—not a sign of a healthy, growing business.

sections.title: Where to Find Dividend Data
sections.content:
Free Resources:
- Yahoo Finance: Basic dividend info, yield, payout ratio
- Seeking Alpha: Dividend history, analysis articles
- Dividend.com: Comprehensive dividend data and screeners
- Simply Safe Dividends: Dividend safety scores (limited free access)

Broker Tools:
- Fidelity, Schwab, and Vanguard all have dividend screeners
- Filter by yield, growth rate, payout ratio, and sector

Key Data Points to Check:
- Current yield and 5-year average yield
- Dividend growth rate (1, 3, 5, 10 years)
- Payout ratio (earnings and cash flow based)
- Years of consecutive dividend increases
- Ex-dividend dates and payment schedule

sections.title: How to Analyze a Dividend Stock
steps: Check dividend history - has it paid and increased dividends for 10+ years?
Calculate payout ratio - is it under 60% (or 80% for utilities/REITs)?
Review free cash flow - does FCF cover the dividend with room to spare?
Examine debt levels - is debt-to-equity reasonable for the industry?
Analyze earnings trend - are profits growing or declining?
Compare yield to history - is current yield unusually high (potential trouble)?
Read recent news - any red flags like lawsuits, management changes, or guidance cuts?
Check analyst ratings - what do professionals think about dividend safety?

sections.title: The Yield Trap
sections.content: If a stock's yield is much higher than its historical average, ask why. Often it's because the stock price crashed due to problems the market sees. A 7% yield that becomes 3.5% after a dividend cut is worse than a stable 3% yield.

sections.title: Sample Analysis: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)
sections.content:
Let's apply our criteria to a real dividend stock:

Dividend History: 60+ consecutive years of dividend increases (Dividend King)
Current Yield: ~3.0%
Payout Ratio: ~45% of earnings
Free Cash Flow: Dividend well-covered by FCF
Debt/Equity: ~0.4 (conservative)
Earnings Trend: Steady growth over decades

Verdict: High-quality dividend stock. Sustainable dividend with room for growth. The yield isn't exciting, but the safety and growth potential are excellent.

This is what a quality dividend stock looks like—boring, reliable, and likely to keep paying for decades.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: Quality matters more than yield. A 3% yield from a Dividend Aristocrat that grows 8% annually is far better than a 7% yield that gets cut in half. Do your homework before buying any dividend stock.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: You now know how to evaluate dividend stocks. In the next lesson, we'll explore building a diversified dividend portfolio—how many stocks to own, which sectors to include, and how to balance yield with growth.
